titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Whitmore Papers
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 4, 2019 at 04:32

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The George Whitmore Papers consists of the literary papers of the poet, playwright, critic, novelist, and freelance writer George Davis Whitmore. The collection primarily contains his writings and supporting research files, though a small amount of professional correspondence and a few personal papers are present.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Michael Cantor on the Ezra Pound Archive Fund, 1996.

The Whitmore archive was stored by Canter between Whitmore's death in 1989 and transfer of the archive to the library in 1996. According to Canter, Whitmore's "early Kaypro" computer was discarded in 1990 or 1991.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Original computer disks are restricted. Copies of electronic files are available through Access Services. Surrogates of all audio recordings are available within the collection.
Boxes 20-21: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies available. Consult access services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The George Whitmore Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George Whitmore Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In addition to the paper files that document Whitmore's major works in fiction and non-fiction, there are fifty-eight computer disks. In most cases, the electronic documents have corresponding paper printouts in the collection, but readers who would like to consult the electronic files may do so through the Beinecke Library's Access Services staff. The finding aid has been annotated to include these files in their appropriate places within the collection's intellectual arrangement.

The electronic files were migrated by National Data Conversion from the original word-processing software (WordStar for CP/M) to WordStar 4.0 for DOS and to ASCII to maintain readability of data. WordStar 4.0 for DOS and ASCII files were refreshed into the Yale University Library Rescue Repository. Technical specifications are filed with the media in Restricted Fragile.
In this finding aid, the term "typescript" is used to identify papers that Whitmore produced with either a typewriter or a computer and printer.

bioghist.head: George D. Whitmore (1945-1989)
bioghist.p: George Davis Whitmore was a poet, playwright, critic, novelist, and freelance writer, whose lifetime of publishing began with his essays appearing in school literary magazines and ended with his major volume on the AIDS epidemic. He was born in Denver, Colorado, on September 27, 1945, to Lowell and Irene Davis Whitmore. Raised in Denver, he received a BA degree in English and Theatre from MacMurray College in Jacksonville, Illinois, in 1967. Whitmore was awarded a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship and pursued graduate studies in the Theatre Department at Bennington College, Bennington, Vermont. He remained at the college from 1967 to 1968, after which he moved to New York.

Once in the city, Whitmore found employment as an editorial and administrative assistant at two non-profit agencies, Planned Parenthood (1968-1972) and the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York (1972-1981); both positions gave him experience in writing copy, reviewing books, and turning out concise feature articles under deadline. Concurrently, Whitmore maintained a parallel career as a freelance writer, reporter, and critic for several gay periodicals including The Body Politic , Christopher Street , Gay Sunshine , and Gaysweek , as well as serving as contributing editor and literary critic at the San Francisco Advocate from 1974 to 1976. In addition, he wrote on topics of interest to the gay community for other magazines such as the Soho Weekly News , Harper's Weekly , and the Washington Post Book World . His book-length study of Henry David Thoreau was published by the Gay Academic Union in 1977-1978.

Whitmore also worked in fiction throughout his life, composing poetry and short stories that were published in both gay and straight periodicals, as well as issued under his own imprint, the Free Milk Fund Press, which was headquartered in his Upper West Side apartment. He received a New York State CAPS grant for poetry in 1976, and regularly presented his poems at public readings during the 1970s and early 1980s. Three of Whitmore's plays were produced in New York: The Caseworker (1976), Two Plays for Three Women: Flight/The Legacy (1979), and The Rights (1980), and three of his novels were also published there: The Confessions of Danny Slocum (1980), Deep Dish (serialized between 1980 and 1982), and Nebraska (1987). The latter, loosely based on Whitmore's childhood memories, was developed from an earlier unproduced play and written during his residencies at the Edward Albee Foundation (1983) and the MacDowell Colony (1985). Whitmore was a member of a literary group known as the Violet Quill, whose seven authors, as men creating literature for men, are regarded as the strongest voices of the gay male experience in the post-Stonewall era. Christopher Cox, Robert Ferro, Michael Grumley, Andrew Holleran, Felice Picano, Edmund White, and Whitmore met several times in 1979, 1980, and 1981, to read aloud from and discuss their works in progress, as well as those by their friends. Also on their agenda were discussions of how they could work together to promote recognition, acceptance, and publication of gay literature beyond the boundaries of their own community.

In the 1980s, Whitmore worked as a freelance reporter and features writer for popular magazines and newspapers including Travel and Leisure , House and Garden , House Beautiful , and the New York Times ; his specialty was covering people, places, and events connected with art, design, and architecture. At the same time, his personal and professional communities were rapidly being overtaken by the shadow of the AIDS epidemic, as gay male friends and colleagues around him began to sicken and die. Whitmore's response was perhaps his most important contribution to non-fiction literature: three interrelated articles and one book that focused on human face of AIDS. Relying on his reporting skills and journalism contacts, he fashioned the first article for a general public already frightened by rising morbidity statistics: "Reaching Out to Someone with AIDS," a profile of the daily life of an AIDS patient and his volunteer advocate, appeared in The New York Times Magazine on Sunday, May 19, 1985, some months before President Ronald Reagan publicly acknowledged the disease. A second article, "Someone Was Here," ran in GQ the next year. Whitmore reused the title for his 1988 book, Someone Was Here: Profiles in the AIDS Epidemic , which expanded on his Times article by looking at the lives of patients' families and medical professionals as well as the patients themselves, thereby emphasizing the toll of the disease on both the heterosexual and homosexual populations. The book's epilogue was published in advance in the January 31, 1988, issue of The New York Times Magazine . In that essay, "Bearing Witness," Whitmore revealed that he too was a victim of AIDS, having been diagnosed a year after the publication of his "Reaching Out" article. He was 43 years old when he died in New York on April 19, 1989, from AIDS-related complications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The George Whitmore Papers consists of the literary papers of the poet, playwright, critic, novelist, and freelance writer George Davis Whitmore. The collection primarily contains his writings and supporting research files, although there is a small amount of professional correspondence and a few personal papers present. Whitmore's writings span his academic years through his career as a freelance journalist, but nearly half of the collection contains his creative writings, many of which were not published during his lifetime. Whitmore was a member of the Violet Quill group of gay male writers, and most of his literary works reflect his close connection with contemporary gay culture in tone and subject, particularly his AIDS-related writings.

With the exception of one letter from the author to his sister and one to his friend James Ross (Jay) Smith, the collection does not contain personal or family correspondence, health or financial files, daily planners, or any information related to Whitmore's successful human rights lawsuit against the Northern Dispensary. Therefore, the small group of journal entries in Series I are noteworthy for providing the collection's only window on Whitmore's daily activities and inner thoughts.

Among his literary contributions were extensive published interviews with authors William S. Burroughs, Martin Duberman, Tennessee Williams, and Edmund White, and the singing group Labelle (Patti LaBelle, Nona Hendryx, and Sarah Dash), in addition to AIDS patients and care givers. In his fiction and non-fiction work, Whitmore covered topics of relevance to the gay community, and the papers reveal his working methods and resources for his success in both genres.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into six series: I. Personal Papers (1966-1995); II. Writings: Fiction (1959-1989); III. Writings: Non-Fiction, General (before 1967-1988); IV. Writings on AIDS (1984-1989); V. Subject Files (1973-1988); VI. Electronic Files (1981-1986).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a collection of records documenting Whitmore's life: a few pieces of correspondence and photographs, some academic material, a short run of journals, and biographical material including interviews he gave and resumes he wrote. Parts of his academic career are covered by four undergraduate term papers and a set of instructors' reports from his time at Bennington College. AIDS material related to Whitmore's own health conditions is filed in this series, while that which he collected while writing his articles and books on the disease appear in Series IV. The Correspondence file has just a few letters; others can be found in both the folders of the various publications in Series III and in electronic form on several computer disks referenced throughout the finding aid. There are three folders of material related to the "Emma Morris Free Milk Fund," including some of their colorful silk-screened graphics; the Fund appears to have been a humorous club formed and promoted by Whitmore and his friends. Whitmore was awarded two residencies at the MacDowell Colony, in Peterborough, New Hampshire, and went there to write in the fall of 1985 and the spring of 1987. The folders for each visit include a set of snapshot photographs taken during his time at the retreat.

The five folders of journals contain three blank books with manuscript notes as well as sheets of typescript notes detailing Whitmore's activities and inner thoughts, particularly during the months in 1985 when he was researching his article on AIDS for the New York Times . A folder of published interviews and profiles helps to flesh out the abstracts of Whitmore's career and death provided in the resumes and estate papers filed in this series. At the end of the series is a set of manuals and instructions for using Whitmore's Kaypro computer and WordStar software.

The latest item in the collection is a letter filed with Whitmore's correspondence. Dated May 11, 1995, it is from David Bergman to Victor Bumbalo, Whitmore's literary executor. Berman worked with Bumbalo to publish some of Whitmore's writings in his anthology The Violet Quill Reader (1994).

scopecontent.p: Includes one issue of the Bennington College Quadrille

scopecontent.p: Includes user notes and four published manuals

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Novels; Plays; Poetry; and Short Stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series covers Whitmore's creative writings, and holds manuscripts, typescripts, printed versions, clippings, correspondence and contracts, with some research materials.

The first subseries holds files on Whitmore's four novels. The earliest, The Elysium Fire , was a fictionalized work centering on the tragic 1977 fire at the Everard Baths in New York. He did not find a publisher for it, though the Village Voice did print his investigative piece on the fire; a file on that article appears in Series III, and his Everard Baths research files are held in Series V. Whitmore's first published novel, The Confessions of Danny Slocum (St. Martin's Press, 1980) was expanded from a short story that had appeared in the magazine Christopher Street the year before; it was also issued as a paperback (Grey Fox Press, 1985) and optioned for a film. Similarly, his later novel Nebraska (Grove Press, 1987; reprint, Washington Square Press, 1989) had its beginnings as play. The fourth work, Deep Dish , was serialized in the New York Native newspaper between 1980 and 1982.

The Plays subseries contains material on eight of his works for the stage, though only three, The Caseworker , The Rights , and Two Plays for Three Women: Flight/The Legacy , appear to have been produced; the latter piece is about Gertrude Stein.

The Poetry subseries begins with a set of chronologically-grouped poems that had been arranged by Whitmore in dated folders, followed by specifically-grouped pieces and individual works. Many of the poems were self-published, such as those in his "Getting Gay in New York" series: they appeared in several periodicals as well as in various compilations issued by Whitmore's own Free Milk Fund Press. Some of those presentations have decorated paper covers, while others are simply enclosed in commercial pressboard binders. In addition, Whitmore recorded a set of the poems for the use of the blind, and a copy of that audio tape is filed here. His "Cripple Creek" series, supported by a New York State CAPS grant, makes reference to the history of his home state of Colorado, and those files include research material, largely newspaper clippings, related to events mentioned in the poems. At the end of the subseries is a folder of promotional ephemera and correspondence documenting public poetry readings that Whitmore gave between 1972 and 1983, as well as a folder of loose and miscellaneous poems that had been filed with the ephemera. Mostly reproductions but with some original typescripts, they may be the copies from which he read during his appearances.

The Short Stories subseries holds nearly fifty of Whitmore's stories, very few of which appear to have been published. For the most part they are undated; those carrying the date "before 1967" were together in a folder labeled as such by Whitmore. As that is the year of his graduation from MacMurray College, they are likely stories he submitted to high school or college publications; many of these papers have comments, mostly "yes" or "no" with jurors' initials. The story "Bearing Arms" was typed on the verso of copies of his resume and original pages of an unidentified play script.

At the end of the subseries is a bound group of independent tales that Whitmore saw as a "set piece" titled "Out Here: Fire Island Tales." The binder bears Patricia Russell-Loud's paper label and holds photocopies of six stories; the typescripts and printed versions of the same stories are filed alphabetically following the binder. Whitmore's introduction to the bound set lists the other stories that were "in the works" but they are not present among his papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Freelance Projects, and Other Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series covers Whitmore's writings in non-fiction, and holds manuscripts, typescripts, printed versions, clippings, correspondence and contracts, with some research materials. It does not include material on his three articles, book, and lecture on the AIDS crisis; these are held in Series IV, Writings on AIDS.

The Freelance Projects subseries forms the largest part of the series, and contains feature articles, book reviews, and examples of reporting he did as a freelance writer for magazines, newspapers, and newsletters. The files are arranged alphabetically by the title of the periodical that commissioned or paid for the work, though in many cases Whitmore would develop a story idea and pitch it to several different editors. A number of letters and essay samples can also be found by reviewing the electronic files on Disks #43, #45, #46, and #49.

The subseries Other Writings contains miscellaneous works borne of personal interest: his scholarly writings on Edith Sitwell, Henry David Thoreau, and gay poetry; a biographical film treatment that Whitmore created on Marguerite, Countess of Blessington (1789-1849); an editorial that he published in the New York Times ; documentation of presentations he gave on gay culture; and two first-person writings, perhaps autobiographical, about the break-up of a relationship. There is also a single piece of his early career writing, a photocopy of a newsletter from the Citizens Housing & Planning Council. The material is filed alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Whitmore wrote three interrelated articles, one book, and one lecture on the topic of AIDS and the daily lives of its victims. Due to the volume of material involved, these files were organized into a single series. Folders here hold correspondence, contracts, text drafts, page proofs, and printed versions. Also here are Whitmore's research files including transcripts of interviews held with AIDS patients, family members, and care givers, consent forms signed by the interviewees, and folders of fan mail that Whitmore received for three of the projects.

In late 1984 Whitmore pitched an idea to the editor of The New York Times Magazine : an article that would focus on an AIDS patient's relationship with his crisis intervention counselor. Whitmore then worked closely with the Gay Men's Heath Crisis to find appropriate subjects who would agree to have their personal lives made public. "Reaching Out to Someone with AIDS," the story of James Sharp and his advocate Edward Dunn, was published in the magazine on Sunday, May 19, 1985; an offprint was issued afterward by the GMHC and used for fund-raising purposes.
His second article, a first-person essay titled "Someone Was Here: A Gay Man Confronts AIDS," was published in GQ ( Gentlemen's Quarterly ) in April 1986.

Whitmore's book, Someone Was Here: Profiles in the AIDS Epidemic , was published by New American Library in the spring of 1988. It expanded upon his earlier work on Sharp and Dunn by adding to it the stories of a Colorado AIDS patient and his family, and a group of patients and care-givers at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx borough of New York City. The book's epilogue was published in advance of the book. That essay, titled "Bearing Witness," appeared in the Sunday, January 31, 1988, issue of The New York Times Magazine .
The series ends with a folder documenting a presentation on AIDS and identity that Whitmore made at the Brooklyn College Humanities Institute in April 1988.

The electronic files for some of these projects are held in Series VI, on Disks #1 through #11, #16 through #23, and #41. Readers may view these files by applying to the library's Access Services desk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds material kept by Whitmore on a number of topics related to his writings, primarily those of his freelance assignments. Most folders hold brochures, newspaper clippings, maps, and miscellaneous tourist literature, but a few also have pieces of correspondence. Whitmore's research materials on the Everard Baths include an audio recording of his 51-minute interview with fire investigators. The file on Scotland contains two of Whitmore's story ideas in typescript. All literature concerning AIDS is filed in Series I and Series IV.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 18 holds restricted material that may be seen only with permission of the curator.

The series contains fifty-eight 5-1/4-inch computer disks holding electronic versions of some of Whitmore's compositions, drafts, mailing lists, interview notes, journal entries, correspondence, and miscellaneous documents. The files were created using a Kaypro computer and WordStar software, a word processing system for text preparation. The disks were sequentially numbered by Beinecke staff before being sent out for conversion; these numbers are referenced throughout this finding aid. The disk and individual file titles were assigned by Whitmore.
One Kaypro disk box and one Maxell mini-floppy disk box were retained with the disks.

The collection also includes the original software disks that were shipped with the computer. A set of manuals and users guides issued by the company are filed in Series I, along with a single folder with manuscript and typed instructions created by Whitmore.

The list that follows includes only the titles of electronic files with content created by Whitmore; no programming files are listed, nor are blank disks and entire disks of programming software (numbers 32-35, 37-40, 42, 44, and 50-58).
